member.name: T:FlaxEngine.Behavior
member.summary: Behavior instance script that runs Behavior Tree execution.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Behavior.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the .

member.name: E:FlaxEngine.Behavior.Finished
member.summary: Event called when behavior tree execution ends with a result.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Behavior.System
member.summary: The system for behaviors update.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Behavior.Tree
member.summary: Behavior Tree asset to use for logic execution.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Behavior.AutoStart
member.summary: If checked, auto starts the logic on begin play.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Behavior.UpdateRateScale
member.summary: The behavior logic update rate scale (multiplies the UpdateFPS defined in Behavior Tree root node). Can be used to improve performance via LOD to reduce updates frequency (eg. by 0.5) for behaviors far from player.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Behavior.Knowledge
member.summary: Gets the current behavior knowledge instance. Empty if not started.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Behavior.Result
member.summary: Gets the last behavior tree execution result.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Behavior.StartLogic
member.summary: Starts the logic.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Behavior.StopLogic(FlaxEngine.BehaviorUpdateResult)
member.summary: Stops the logic.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Behavior.ResetLogic
member.summary: Resets the behavior logic by clearing knowledge (clears blackboard and removes goals) and resetting execution state (goes back to root).

member.summary: Provides a Mono-like API for native code to access managed runtime.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Interop.NativeInterop.GetFunctionPointerForDelegate``1(``0)
member.summary: Converts a delegate into a function pointer that is callable from unmanaged code via but cached delegate to prevent collecting it by GC.
member.typeparam: The type of delegate to convert.
member.param: The delegate to be passed to unmanaged code.
member.returns: A value that can be passed to unmanaged code, which, in turn, can use it to call the underlying managed delegate.

member.returns: Output array.

member.summary: Converts managed array wrapper into array of GC Handles for native runtime.
member.returns: Output array.

Otherwise, event execution will be delayed until the sync point of the animated model and called from the main thread. Async events need to precisely handle data access, especially when it comes to editing scene objects with multi-threading.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.AudioListener
member.summary: Represents a listener that hears audio sources. For spatial audio the volume and pitch of played audio is determined by the distance, orientation and velocity differences between the source and the listener.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the .

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioListener.Velocity
member.summary: Gets the velocity of the listener. Determines pitch in relation to AudioListener's position.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.AudioSource
member.summary: Represents a source for emitting audio. Audio can be played spatially (gun shot), or normally (music). Each audio source must have an AudioClip to play - back, and it can also have a position in the case of spatial (3D) audio.
member.remarks: Whether or not an audio source is spatial is controlled by the assigned AudioClip.The volume and the pitch of a spatial audio source is controlled by its position and the AudioListener's position/direction/velocity.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the .

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Clip
member.summary: The audio clip asset used as a source of the sound.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Velocity
member.summary: Gets the velocity of the source. Determines pitch in relation to AudioListener's position. Only relevant for spatial (3D) sources.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Volume
member.summary: Gets or sets the volume of the audio played from this source, in [0, 1] range.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Pitch
member.summary: Gets or sets the pitch of the played audio. The default is 1.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Pan
member.summary: Gets or sets the stereo pan of the played audio (-1 is left speaker, 1 is right speaker, 0 is balanced). The default is 1. Used by non-spatial audio only.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.IsLooping
member.summary: Determines whether the audio clip should loop when it finishes playing.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.PlayOnStart
member.summary: Determines whether the audio clip should autoplay on level start.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.StartTime
member.summary: Determines the time (in seconds) at which the audio clip starts playing if Play On Start is enabled.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.MinDistance
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum distance at which audio attenuation starts. When the listener is closer to the source than this value, audio is heard at full volume. Once farther away the audio starts attenuating.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Attenuation
member.summary: Gets or sets the attenuation that controls how quickly does audio volume drop off as the listener moves further from the source.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.DopplerFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the doppler effect factor. Scale for source velocity. Default is 1.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.AllowSpatialization
member.summary: If checked, source can play spatial 3d audio (when audio clip supports it), otherwise will always play as 2d sound.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.State
member.summary: Gets the current state of the audio playback (playing/paused/stopped).

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Time
member.summary: Gets or sets the current time of playback. If playback has not yet started, it specifies the time at which playback will start at. The time is in seconds, in range [0, ClipLength].

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.Is3D
member.summary: Returns true if the sound source is three-dimensional (volume and pitch varies based on listener distance and velocity).

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.UseStreaming
member.summary: Returns true if audio clip is valid, loaded and uses dynamic data streaming.

member.summary: Determines whether this audio source started playing audio via audio backend. After audio play it may wait for audio clip data to be loaded or streamed. [Deprecated in v1.9]

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.AudioSource.IsActuallyPlaying
member.summary: Determines whether this audio source started playing audio via audio backend. After audio play it may wait for audio clip data to be loaded or streamed.

member.summary: True if generate mip maps chain for the texture.

member.summary: True if flip X coordinate of the texture (Flips over Y axis).

member.summary: True if to invert the green channel on a normal map. Good for OpenGL to DirectX conversion.

member.summary: Rebuild Z (blue) channel assuming X/Y are normals.

member.summary: Texture size scale. Allows increasing or decreasing the imported texture resolution. Default is 1.

member.summary: Maximum size of the texture (for both width and height). Higher resolution textures will be resized during importing process. Used to clip textures that are too big.

member.summary: True if resize texture on import. Use SizeX/SizeY properties to define texture width and height. Texture scale property will be ignored.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.Tools.TextureTool.Options.KeepAspectRatio
member.summary: Keeps the aspect ratio when resizing.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.Tools.TextureTool.Options.SizeX
member.summary: The width of the imported texture. If Resize property is set to true then texture will be resized during the import to this value during the import, otherwise it will be ignored.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.Tools.TextureTool.Options.SizeY
member.summary: The height of the imported texture. If Resize property is set to true then texture will be resized during the import to this value during the import, otherwise it will be ignored.

member.summary: The reference value for the alpha coverage preserving.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Model.GenerateSDF(System.Single,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Generates the Sign Distant Field for this model.
member.remarks: Can be called in async in case of SDF generation on a CPU (assuming model is not during rendering).
member.param: The SDF texture resolution scale. Use higher values for more precise data but with significant performance and memory overhead.
The index of the LOD to use for the SDF building.
If true, the generated SDF texture data will be cached on CPU (in asset chunk storage) to allow saving it later, otherwise it will be runtime for GPU-only. Ignored for virtual assets or in build.
Custom threshold (in range 0-1) for adjusting mesh internals detection based on the percentage of test rays hit triangle backfaces. Use lower value for more dense mesh.
Enables using GPU for SDF generation, otherwise CPU will be used (async via Job System).
member.returns: True if failed, otherwise false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Content.Load(System.Guid,System.Double)
member.summary: Loads asset to the Content Pool and holds it until it won't be referenced by any object. Returns null if asset is missing. Actual asset data loading is performed on a other thread in async. The current thread execution is blocked until asset is loaded. Waits until asset will be loaded. It's equivalent to LoadAsync + WaitForLoaded.
member.returns: Asset instance if loaded, null otherwise

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Transpose
member.summary: Transposes the matrix.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified matrix.
member.returns: The orthogonalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the matrix will be orthogonal to any other given row in the matrix.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified matrix.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized matrix.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting matrix tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.
This operation is performed on the rows of the matrix rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.UpperTriangularForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular matrix.
member.remarks: If the matrix is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the matrix represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix.ReducedRowEchelonForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Float4@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Float4@)
member.summary: Brings the matrix into reduced row echelon form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The matrix to put into reduced row echelon form.
The fifth column of the matrix.
When the method completes, contains the resultant matrix after the operation.
When the method completes, contains the resultant fifth column of the matrix.

remarks.para: The fifth column is often called the augmented part of the matrix. This is because the fifth column is really just an extension of the matrix so that there is a place to put all of the non-zero components after the operation is complete.
Often times the resultant matrix will the identity matrix or a matrix similar to the identity matrix. Sometimes, however, that is not possible and numbers other than zero and one may appear.

This method can be used to solve systems of linear equations. Upon completion of this method, the will contain the solution for the system. It is up to the user to analyze both the input and the result to determine if a solution really exists.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthogonalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthogonalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.returns: The orthogonalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all rows orthogonal to each other. This means that any given row in the Matrix3x3 will be orthogonal to any other given row in the Matrix3x3.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the orthonormalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.Orthonormalize(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3)
member.summary: Orthonormalizes the specified Matrix3x3.
member.returns: The orthonormalized Matrix3x3.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all rows and columns orthogonal to each other and making all rows and columns of unit length. This means that any given row will be orthogonal to any other given row and any given column will be orthogonal to any other given column. Any given row will not be orthogonal to any given column. Every row and every column will be of unit length.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting Matrix3x3 tends to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the rows so that the first row is the most stable and the last row is the least stable.

This operation is performed on the rows of the Matrix3x3 rather than the columns. If you wish for this operation to be performed on the columns, first transpose the input and than transpose the output.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3.UpperTriangularForm(FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix3x3@)
member.summary: Brings the Matrix3x3 into upper triangular form using elementary row operations.
member.param: The Matrix3x3 to put into upper triangular form.
When the method completes, contains the upper triangular Matrix3x3.
member.remarks: If the Matrix3x3 is not invertible (i.e. its determinant is zero) than the result of this method may produce Single.Nan and Single.Inf values. When the Matrix3x3 represents a system of linear equations, than this often means that either no solution exists or an infinite number of solutions exist.

member.param: Value between 0 and 1 indicating the weight of .
When the method completes, contains the linear interpolation of the two quaternions.
member.remarks: This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula. start + (end - start) * amount Passing a value of 0 will cause to be returned; a value of 1 will cause to be returned.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Float2.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Float2@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Float2@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Float2.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Float2,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.returns: The transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Float2.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Float2@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Float2@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Float2.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Float2,FlaxEngine.Matrix)

This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Float3.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Float3,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.returns: The transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Float3.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Float3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Float3@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Float3.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Float3,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.returns: The transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Double2.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Double2@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Double2@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Double2.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Double2,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.returns: The transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Double2.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Double2@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Double2@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Double2.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Double2,FlaxEngine.Matrix)

This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Int2.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Int2@,FlaxEngine.Int2@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Double3.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Double3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Double3@)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Double3.TransformCoordinate(FlaxEngine.Double3,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a coordinate transformation using the given .
member.returns: The transformed coordinates.
member.remarks: A coordinate transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is one. The four dimensional vector obtained from the transformation operation has each component in the vector divided by the w component. This forces the w component to be one and therefore makes the vector homogeneous. The homogeneous vector is often preferred when working with coordinates as the w component can safely be ignored.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Double3.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Double3@,FlaxEngine.Matrix@,FlaxEngine.Double3@)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the transformed normal.
member.remarks: A normal transform performs the transformation with the assumption that the w component is zero. This causes the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix to be unused. The end result is a vector that is not translated, but all other transformation properties apply. This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Double3.TransformNormal(FlaxEngine.Double3,FlaxEngine.Matrix)
member.summary: Performs a normal transformation using the given .
member.returns: The transformed normal.

This is often preferred for normal vectors as normals purely represent direction rather than location because normal vectors should not be translated.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Int3.DistanceSquared(FlaxEngine.Int3@,FlaxEngine.Int3@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.summary: Determines if there is an intersection between the current object or any it's child and a ray.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection (if any valid).
When the method completes, contains the intersection surface normal vector (if any valid).
When the method completes, contains zero-based index of the foliage instance that is the closest to the ray.
member.returns: True whether the two objects intersected, otherwise false.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.FeatureLevel
member.summary: Graphics feature levels indicates what level of support can be relied upon. They are named after the graphics API to indicate the minimum level of the features set to support. Feature levels are ordered from the lowest to the most high-end so feature level enum can be used to switch between feature levels (e.g. don't use geometry shader if not supported).

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage
member.summary: Identifies expected GPU resource use during rendering. The usage directly reflects whether a resource is accessible by the CPU and/or the GPU.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage.Default
member.summary: A resource that requires read and write access by the GPU. This is likely to be the most common usage choice. Memory will be used on device only, so fast access from the device is preferred. It usually means device-local GPU (video) memory.
member.remarks: Usage: - Resources written and read by device, e.g. images used as render targets. - Resources transferred from host once (immutable) or infrequently and read by device multiple times, e.g. textures to be sampled, vertex buffers, constant buffers, and majority of other types of resources used on GPU.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage.Dynamic
member.summary: A resource that is accessible by both the GPU (read only) and the CPU (write only). A dynamic resource is a good choice for a resource that will be updated by the CPU at least once per frame. Dynamic buffers or textures are usually used to upload data to GPU and use it within a single frame.
member.remarks: Usage: - Resources written frequently by CPU (dynamic), read by device. E.g. textures, vertex buffers, uniform buffers updated every frame or every draw call.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage.StagingUpload
member.summary: A resource that supports data transfer (copy) from the CPU to the GPU. It usually means CPU (system) memory. Resources created in this pool may still be accessible to the device, but access to them can be slow.
member.remarks: Usage: - Staging copy of resources used as transfer source.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GPUResourceUsage.StagingReadback
member.summary: A resource that supports data transfer (copy) from the GPU to the CPU.
member.remarks: Usage: - Resources written by device, read by host - results of some computations, e.g. screen capture, average scene luminance for HDR tone mapping. - Any resources read or accessed randomly on host, e.g. CPU-side copy of vertex buffer used as source of transfer, but also used for collision detection.

member.summary: Describes how a mapped GPU resource will be accessed.

member.summary: The resource is mapped for reading.

member.summary: The resource is mapped for writing.

member.summary: The resource is mapped for reading and writing.

member.summary: Gets the opaque rendering (default). No blending is being performed.

member.summary: Gets the additive rendering. Adds the color and the alpha channel. Source color is multiplied by the alpha.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.AlphaBlend
member.summary: Gets the alpha blending. Source alpha controls the output color (0 - use destination color, 1 - use source color).

member.summary: Gets the additive blending with pre-multiplied color.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Multiply
member.summary: Gets the multiply blending (multiply output color with texture color).

member.summary: The default .

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend
member.summary: Blending mode.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.Zero
member.summary: The blend factor is (0, 0, 0, 0). No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.One
member.summary: The blend factor is (1, 1, 1, 1). No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.SrcColor
member.summary: The blend factor is (Rs, Gs, Bs, As), that is color data (RGB) from a pixel shader. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvSrcColor
member.summary: The blend factor is (1 - Rs, 1 - Gs, 1 - Bs, 1 - As), that is color data (RGB) from a pixel shader. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - RGB.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.SrcAlpha
member.summary: The blend factor is (As, As, As, As), that is alpha data (A) from a pixel shader. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvSrcAlpha
member.summary: The blend factor is ( 1 - As, 1 - As, 1 - As, 1 - As), that is alpha data (A) from a pixel shader. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - A.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.DestAlpha
member.summary: The blend factor is (Ad Ad Ad Ad), that is alpha data from a render target. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvDestAlpha
member.summary: The blend factor is (1 - Ad 1 - Ad 1 - Ad 1 - Ad), that is alpha data from a render target. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - A.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.DestColor
member.summary: The blend factor is (Rd, Gd, Bd, Ad), that is color data from a render target. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvDestColor
member.summary: The blend factor is (1 - Rd, 1 - Gd, 1 - Bd, 1 - Ad), that is color data from a render target. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - RGB.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.SrcAlphaSat
member.summary: The blend factor is (f, f, f, 1); where f = min(As, 1 - Ad). The pre-blend operation clamps the data to 1 or less.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.BlendFactor
member.summary: The blend factor is the blend factor set with GPUContext.SetBlendFactor. No pre-blend operation.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.BlendInvFactor
member.summary: The blend factor is the blend factor set with GPUContext.SetBlendFactor. The pre-blend operation inverts the blend factor, generating 1 - blend_factor.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.Src1Color
member.summary: The blend factor is data sources both as color data output by a pixel shader. There is no pre-blend operation. This blend factor supports dual-source color blending.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvSrc1Color
member.summary: The blend factor is data sources both as color data output by a pixel shader. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - RGB. This blend factor supports dual-source color blending.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.Src1Alpha
member.summary: The blend factor is data sources as alpha data output by a pixel shader. There is no pre-blend operation. This blend factor supports dual-source color blending.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BlendingMode.Blend.InvSrc1Alpha
member.summary: The blend factor is data sources as alpha data output by a pixel shader. The pre-blend operation inverts the data, generating 1 - A. This blend factor supports dual-source color blending.

member.summary: The count of items in the Blend enum.

member.summary: Render the material after custom post effects (scripted).

member.summary: Render the material after anti-aliasing into the output backbuffer.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation
member.summary: The Post Process effect rendering location within the rendering pipeline.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.Default
member.summary: The default location after the in-build PostFx pass (bloom, color grading, etc.) but before anti-aliasing effect.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.BeforePostProcessingPass
member.summary: The 'before' in-build PostFx pass (bloom, color grading, etc.). After Forward Pass (transparency) and fog effects.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.BeforeForwardPass
member.summary: The 'before' Forward pass (transparency) and fog effects. After the Light pass and Reflections pass.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.BeforeReflectionsPass
member.summary: The 'before' Reflections pass. After the Light pass. Can be used to implement a custom light types that accumulate lighting to the light buffer.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.AfterAntiAliasingPass
member.summary: The 'after' AA filter pass.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.CustomUpscale
member.summary: The custom frame up-scaling that replaces default implementation. Rendering is done to the output backbuffer (use OutputView and OutputViewport as render destination).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.AfterGBufferPass
member.summary: The 'after' GBuffer rendering pass. Can be used to render custom geometry into GBuffer. Output is light buffer, single-target only (no output).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.AfterForwardPass
member.summary: The 'after' forward pass but before any post processing.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffectLocation.MAX
member.summary: The count of items in the PostProcessEffectLocation enum.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.GPUBuffer.DownloadData(System.Byte[]@)
member.summary: Stops current thread execution to gather buffer data from the GPU. Cannot be called from main thread if the buffer is not a dynamic nor staging readback.
member.returns: True if cannot download data, otherwise false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.GPUBuffer.GetData(System.Byte[]@)
member.summary: Gets the buffer data via map/memcpy/unmap sequence. Always supported for dynamic and staging readback buffers (other types support depends on graphics backend implementation).
member.returns: True if failed, otherwise false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.GPUBuffer.SetData(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Sets the buffer data via map/memcpy/unmap sequence. Always supported for dynamic buffers (other types support depends on graphics backend implementation).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.GPUBuffer.Map(FlaxEngine.GPUResourceMapMode)
member.summary: Gets a CPU pointer to the resource by mapping its contents. Denies the GPU access to that resource.
member.remarks: Always call Unmap if the returned pointer is valid to release resources.
member.returns: The pointer of the mapped CPU buffer with resource data or null if failed.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.GPUBuffer.Unmap
member.summary: Invalidates the mapped pointer to a resource and restores the GPU's access to that resource.

member.summary: True if device supports Geometry shaders.

member.summary: True if device supports separate render target blending states.

member.summary: True if device supports depth buffer clipping (see GPUPipelineState.Description.DepthClipEnable).

member.summary: True if device supports multisampled depth buffer texture as a shader resource view.

member.summary: True if device supports reading from typed UAV in shader (common types such as R32G32B32A32, R16G16B16A16, R16, R8). This doesn't apply to single-component 32-bit formats.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.Graphics
member.summary: Graphics device manager that creates, manages and releases graphics device and related objects.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.UseVSync
member.summary: Enables rendering synchronization with the refresh rate of the display device to avoid "tearing" artifacts.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.AAQuality
member.summary: Anti Aliasing quality setting.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.SSRQuality
member.summary: Screen Space Reflections quality setting.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.SSAOQuality
member.summary: Screen Space Ambient Occlusion quality setting.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.VolumetricFogQuality
member.summary: Volumetric Fog quality setting.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.ShadowsQuality
member.summary: The shadows quality.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.ShadowMapsQuality
member.summary: The shadow maps quality (textures resolution).

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.ShadowUpdateRate
member.summary: The global scale for all shadow maps update rate. Can be used to slow down shadows rendering frequency on lower quality settings or low-end platforms. Default 1.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.AllowCSMBlending
member.summary: Enables cascades splits blending for directional light shadows. [Deprecated in v1.9]

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.GlobalSDFQuality
member.summary: The Global SDF quality. Controls the volume texture resolution and amount of cascades to use.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.GIQuality
member.summary: The Global Illumination quality. Controls the quality of the GI effect.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.GICascadesBlending
member.summary: Enables cascades splits blending for Global Illumination.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.PostProcessSettings
member.summary: The default Post Process settings. Can be overriden by PostFxVolume on a level locally, per camera or for a whole map.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.Graphics.SpreadWorkload
member.summary: Debug utility to toggle graphics workloads amortization over several frames by systems such as shadows mapping, global illumination or surface atlas. Can be used to test performance in the worst-case scenario (eg. camera-cut).

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain
member.summary: Material domain type. Material domain defines the target usage of the material shader.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Surface
member.summary: The surface material. Can be used to render the scene geometry including models and skinned models.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.PostProcess
member.summary: The post process material. Can be used to perform custom post-processing of the rendered frame.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Decal
member.summary: The deferred decal material. Can be used to apply custom overlay or surface modifications to the object surfaces in the world.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.GUI
member.summary: The GUI shader. Can be used to draw custom control interface elements or to add custom effects to the GUI.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Terrain
member.summary: The terrain shader. Can be used only with landscape chunks geometry that use optimized vertex data and support multi-layered blending.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Particle
member.summary: The particle shader. Can be used only with particles geometry (sprites, trails and ribbons). Supports reading particle data on a GPU.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.Deformable
member.summary: The deformable shader. Can be used only with objects that can be deformed (spline models).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.VolumeParticle
member.summary: The particle shader used for volumetric effects rendering such as Volumetric Fog.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDomain.MAX
member.summary: The count of items in the MaterialDomain enum.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode
member.summary: Material blending modes.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode.Opaque
member.summary: The opaque material. Used during GBuffer pass rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode.Transparent
member.summary: The transparent material. Used during Forward pass rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode.Additive
member.summary: The additive blend. Material color is used to add to color of the objects behind the surface. Used during Forward pass rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialBlendMode.Multiply
member.summary: The multiply blend. Material color is used to multiply color of the objects behind the surface. Used during Forward pass rendering.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel
member.summary: Material shading modes. Defines how material inputs and properties are combined to result the final surface color.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel.Unlit
member.summary: The unlit material. The emissive channel is used as an output color. Can perform custom lighting operations or just glow. Won't be affected by the lighting pipeline.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel.Lit
member.summary: The default lit material. The most common choice for the material surfaces.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel.Subsurface
member.summary: The subsurface material. Intended for materials like wax or skin that need light scattering to transport simulation through the object.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialShadingModel.Foliage
member.summary: The foliage material. Intended for foliage materials like leaves and grass that need light scattering to transport simulation through the thin object.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags
member.summary: Material features flags.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.None
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.Wireframe
member.summary: The wireframe material.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.DisableDepthTest
member.summary: The depth test is disabled (material ignores depth).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.DisableDepthWrite
member.summary: Disable depth buffer write (won't modify depth buffer value during rendering).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.InputWorldSpaceNormal
member.summary: The flag used to indicate that material input normal vector is defined in the world space rather than tangent space.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.DitheredLODTransition
member.summary: The flag used to indicate that material uses dithered model LOD transition for smoother LODs switching.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.DisableFog
member.summary: The flag used to disable fog. The Forward Pass materials option.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.DisableReflections
member.summary: The flag used to disable reflections. The Forward Pass materials option.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.DisableDistortion
member.summary: The flag used to disable distortion effect (light refraction). The Forward Pass materials option.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.PixelNormalOffsetRefraction
member.summary: The flag used to enable refraction offset based on the difference between the per-pixel normal and the per-vertex normal. Useful for large water-like surfaces.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.ScreenSpaceReflections
member.summary: The flag used to enable high-quality reflections based on the screen space raytracing. Useful for large water-like surfaces. The Forward Pass materials option.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialFeaturesFlags.GlobalIllumination
member.summary: The flag used to enable sampling Global Illumination in material (eg. light probes or volumetric lightmap). The Forward Pass materials option.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags
member.summary: Material features usage flags. Detected by the material generator to help graphics pipeline optimize rendering of material shaders.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.None
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseMask
member.summary: Material is using mask to discard some pixels. Masked materials are using full vertex buffer during shadow maps and depth pass rendering (need UVs).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseEmissive
member.summary: The material is using emissive light.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UsePositionOffset
member.summary: The material is using world position offset (it may be animated inside a shader).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseVertexColor
member.summary: The material is using vertex colors. The render will try to feed the pipeline with a proper buffer so material can gather valid data.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseNormal
member.summary: The material is using per-pixel normal mapping.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseDisplacement
member.summary: The material is using position displacement (in domain shader).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialUsageFlags.UseRefraction
member.summary: The flag used to indicate that material uses refraction feature.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialDecalBlendingMode
member.summary: Decal material blending modes.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDecalBlendingMode.Translucent
member.summary: Decal will be fully blended with the material surface.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDecalBlendingMode.Stain
member.summary: Decal color will be blended with the material surface color (using multiplication).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDecalBlendingMode.Normal
member.summary: Decal will blend the normal vector only.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialDecalBlendingMode.Emissive
member.summary: Decal will apply the emissive light only.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.MaterialTransparentLightingMode
member.summary: Transparent material lighting modes.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialTransparentLightingMode.Surface
member.summary: Default directional lighting evaluated per-pixel at the material surface. Use it for semi-transparent surfaces - with both diffuse and specular lighting components active.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.MaterialTransparentLightingMode.SurfaceNonDirectional
member.summary: Non-directional lighting evaluated per-pixel at material surface. Use it for volumetric objects such as smoke, rain or dust - only the diffuse lighting term is active (no specular highlights).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer0(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the first vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer1(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the second vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer2(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the third vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh has no vertex colors (stored in vertex buffer 2) the returned value is null.
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data or null if mesh has no vertex colors.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadVertexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the raw vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadIndexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the index buffer that contains mesh triangles data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh index buffer format (see ) is then it's faster to call .
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.Mesh.DownloadIndexBufferUShort(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the index buffer that contains mesh triangles data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh index buffer format (see ) is then data won't be downloaded.
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.UpdateMesh(FlaxEngine.Float3[],System.Int32[],FlaxEngine.Int4[],FlaxEngine.Float4[],FlaxEngine.Float3[],FlaxEngine.Float3[],FlaxEngine.Float2[])
member.summary: Updates the skinned model mesh vertex and index buffer data. Can be used only for virtual assets (see and ). Mesh data will be cached and uploaded to the GPU with a delay.
member.param: The mesh vertices positions. Cannot be null.
The mesh index buffer (clockwise triangles). Uses 32-bit stride buffer. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend indices buffer. Contains indices of the skeleton bones (up to 4 bones per vertex) to use for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The skinned mesh blend weights buffer (normalized). Contains weights per blend bone (up to 4 bones per vertex) of the skeleton bones to mix for vertex position blending. Cannot be null.
The normal vectors (per vertex). Use null to compute them from normal vectors.

Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.DownloadVertexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the raw vertex buffer that contains mesh vertices data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.DownloadIndexBuffer(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the index buffer that contains mesh triangles data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh index buffer format (see ) is then it's faster to call .
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.SkinnedMesh.DownloadIndexBufferUShort(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Downloads the index buffer that contains mesh triangles data. To download data from GPU set to true and call this method from the thread other than main thread (see ).
member.remarks: If mesh index buffer format (see ) is then data won't be downloaded.
member.param: If set to true the data will be downloaded from the GPU, otherwise it can be loaded from the drive (source asset file) or from memory (if cached). Downloading mesh from GPU requires this call to be made from the other thread than main thread. Virtual assets are always downloaded from GPU memory due to lack of dedicated storage container for the asset data.
member.returns: The gathered data.

member.summary: A 32-bit floating-point component, and two typeless components (with an additional 32 bits). This format supports 32-bit red channel, 8 bits are unused, and 24 bits are unused.

member.summary: A 32-bit typeless component, and two unsigned-integer components (with an additional 32 bits). This format has 32 bits unused, 8 bits for green channel, and 24 bits are unused.

member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit typeless format that supports 10 bits for each color and 2 bits for alpha.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R11G11B10_Float
member.summary: Three partial-precision floating-point numbers encoded into a single 32-bit value (a variant of s10e5, which is sign bit, 10-bit mantissa, and 5-bit biased (15) exponent). There are no sign bits, and there is a 5-bit biased (15) exponent for each channel, 6-bit mantissa for R and G, and a 5-bit mantissa for B.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R9G9B9E5_SharedExp
member.summary: Three partial-precision floating-point numbers encoded into a single 32-bit value all sharing the same 5-bit exponent (variant of s10e5, which is sign bit, 10-bit mantissa, and 5-bit biased (15) exponent). There is no sign bit, and there is a shared 5-bit biased (15) exponent and a 9-bit mantissa for each channel.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.R8G8_B8G8_UNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-normalized-integer format. This packed RGB format is analogous to the UYVY format. Each 32-bit block describes a pair of pixels: (R8, G8, B8) and (R8, G8, B8) where the R8/B8 values are repeated, and the G8 values are unique to each pixel. Width must be even.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.G8R8_G8B8_UNorm
member.summary: A four-component, 32-bit unsigned-normalized-integer format. This packed RGB format is analogous to the YUY2 format. Each 32-bit block describes a pair of pixels: (R8, G8, B8) and (R8, G8, B8) where the R8/B8 values are repeated, and the G8 values are unique to each pixel. Width must be even.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.YUY2
member.summary: Packed YUV 4:2:2 video texture format. The mapping to the view channel in shader is Y0->R8, U0->G8, Y1->B8, and V0->A8.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.PixelFormat.NV12
member.summary: Packed YUV 4:2:0 video texture format. Texture uses separate views to access the luma (Y) plane separately from the chroma (UV) planes. For luminance data view, the mapping to the view channel is Y->R8. For chrominance data view, the mapping to the view channel is U->R8 and V->G8.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.IsHDR(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified is HDR (either 16 or 32bits Float)
member.returns: true if the specified pixel format is HDR (Floating poInt); otherwise, false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.IsRgbAOrder(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified format is in RGBA order.
member.returns: true if the specified format is in RGBA order; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.IsBGRAOrder(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified format is in BGRA order.
member.returns: true if the specified format is in BGRA order; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.IsNormalized(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified format contains normalized data. It indicates that values stored in an integer format are to be mapped to the range [-1,1] (for signed values) or [0,1] (for unsigned values) when they are accessed and converted to floating point.
member.returns: True if given format contains normalized data type, otherwise false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.IsInteger(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified format is integer data type (signed or unsigned).
member.returns: True if given format contains integer data type (signed or unsigned), otherwise false.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.ComputeComponentsCount(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Computes the format components count (number of R, G, B, A channels).
member.returns: The components count.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.ComputeBlockSize(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Computes the amount of pixels per-axis stored in the a single block of the format (eg. 4 for BC-family). Returns 1 for uncompressed formats.
member.returns: The block pixels count.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.TosRGB(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Finds the equivalent sRGB format to the provided format.
member.returns: The equivalent sRGB format if any, the provided format else.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.ToNonsRGB(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Finds the equivalent non sRGB format to the provided sRGB format.
member.returns: The equivalent non sRGB format if any, the provided format else.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.MakeTypeless(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Converts the format to typeless.
member.returns: The typeless format.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.MakeTypelessFloat(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Converts the typeless format to float.
member.returns: The float format.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PixelFormatExtensions.MakeTypelessUNorm(FlaxEngine.PixelFormat)
member.summary: Converts the typeless format to unorm.
member.returns: The unorm format.

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect
member.summary: Custom PostFx which can modify final image by processing it with material based filters. The base class for all post process effects used by the graphics pipeline. Allows to extend frame rendering logic and apply custom effects such as outline, night vision, contrast etc.
member.remarks: Override this class and implement custom post fx logic. Use MainRenderTask.Instance.AddCustomPostFx(myPostFx) to attach your script to rendering or add script to camera actor.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the .

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Location
member.summary: Effect rendering location within rendering pipeline.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.UseSingleTarget
member.summary: True whether use a single render target as both input and output. Use this if your effect doesn't need to copy the input buffer to the output but can render directly to the single texture. Can be used to optimize game performance.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Order
member.summary: Effect rendering order. Post effects are sorted before rendering (from the lowest order to the highest order).

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.CanRender
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this effect can be rendered.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.CanRender(FlaxEngine.RenderContext)
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this effect can be rendered.

member.name: M:FlaxEngine.PostProcessEffect.Render(FlaxEngine.GPUContext,FlaxEngine.RenderContext@,FlaxEngine.GPUTexture,FlaxEngine.GPUTexture)
member.summary: Performs custom postFx rendering.

member.summary: Global Illumination infinite indirect lighting bounce intensity scale. Can be used to boost or reduce GI effect for the light bouncing on the surfaces.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GlobalIlluminationSettings.TemporalResponse
member.summary: Defines how quickly GI blends between the current frame and the history buffer. Lower values update GI faster, but with more jittering and noise. If the camera in your game doesn't move much, we recommend values closer to 1.

member.summary: Draw distance of the Global Illumination effect. Scene outside the range will use fallback irradiance.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.GlobalIlluminationSettings.FallbackIrradiance
member.summary: The irradiance lighting outside the GI range used as a fallback to prevent pure-black scene outside the Global Illumination range.

member.summary: The default .

member.summary: If checked, bloom effect will be rendered.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BloomSettings.Intensity
member.summary: Bloom effect strength. Set a value of 0 to disabled it, while higher values increase the effect.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BloomSettings.Threshold
member.summary: Minimum pixel brightness value to start blooming. Values below this threshold are skipped.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BloomSettings.BlurSigma
member.summary: This affects the fall-off of the bloom. It's the standard deviation (sigma) used in the Gaussian blur formula when calculating the kernel of the bloom.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.BloomSettings.Limit
member.summary: Bloom effect brightness limit. Pixels with higher luminance will be capped to this brightness level.

member.summary: The default .

member.summary: Contains settings for Tone Mapping effect rendering.

member.summary: The flags for overriden properties.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings.WhiteTemperature
member.summary: Adjusts the white balance in relation to the temperature of the light in the scene. When the light temperature and this one match the light will appear white. When a value is used that is higher than the light in the scene it will yield a "warm" or yellow color, and, conversely, if the value is lower, it would yield a "cool" or blue color.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings.WhiteTint
member.summary: Adjusts the white balance temperature tint for the scene by adjusting the cyan and magenta color ranges. Ideally, this setting should be used once you've adjusted the white balance temperature to get accurate colors. Under some light temperatures, the colors may appear to be more yellow or blue. This can be used to balance the resulting color to look more natural.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings.Mode
member.summary: The tone mapping mode to use for the color grading process.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.ToneMappingSettings.Default
member.summary: The default .

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings
member.summary: Contains settings for Eye Adaptation effect rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.OverrideFlags
member.summary: The flags for overriden properties.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.Mode
member.summary: The effect rendering mode used for the exposure processing.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.SpeedUp
member.summary: The speed at which the exposure changes when the scene brightness moves from a dark area to a bright area (brightness goes up).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.SpeedDown
member.summary: The speed at which the exposure changes when the scene brightness moves from a bright area to a dark area (brightness goes down).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.PreExposure
member.summary: The pre-exposure value applied to the scene color before performing post-processing (such as bloom, lens flares, etc.).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.PostExposure
member.summary: The post-exposure value applied to the scene color after performing post-processing (such as bloom, lens flares, etc.) but before color grading and tone mapping.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.MinBrightness
member.summary: The minimum brightness for the auto exposure which limits the lower brightness the eye can adapt within.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.MaxBrightness
member.summary: The maximum brightness for the auto exposure which limits the upper brightness the eye can adapt within.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.HistogramLowPercent
member.summary: The lower bound for the luminance histogram of the scene color. This value is in percent and limits the pixels below this brightness. Use values in the range of 60-80. Used only in AutomaticHistogram mode.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.HistogramHighPercent
member.summary: The upper bound for the luminance histogram of the scene color. This value is in percent and limits the pixels above this brightness. Use values in the range of 80-95. Used only in AutomaticHistogram mode.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.EyeAdaptationSettings.Default
member.summary: The default .

member.name: T:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings
member.summary: Contains settings for Depth Of Field effect rendering.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.OverrideFlags
member.summary: The flags for overriden properties.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.Enabled
member.summary: If checked, the depth of field effect will be visible.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BlurStrength
member.summary: The blur intensity in the out-of-focus areas. Allows reducing the blur amount by scaling down the Gaussian Blur radius. Normalized to range 0-1.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.FocalDistance
member.summary: The distance in World Units from the camera that acts as the center of the region where the scene is perfectly in focus and no blurring occurs.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.FocalRegion
member.summary: The distance in World Units beyond the focal distance where the scene is perfectly in focus and no blurring occurs.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.NearTransitionRange
member.summary: The distance in World Units from the focal region on the side nearer to the camera over which the scene transitions from focused to blurred.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.FarTransitionRange
member.summary: The distance in World Units from the focal region on the side farther from the camera over which the scene transitions from focused to blurred.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.DepthLimit
member.summary: The distance in World Units which describes border after that there is no blur (useful to disable DoF on sky). Use 0 to disable that feature.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehEnabled
member.summary: If checked, bokeh shapes will be rendered.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehSize
member.summary: Controls size of the bokeh shapes.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehBrightness
member.summary: Controls brightness of the bokeh shapes. Can be used to fade them or make more intense.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehShape
member.summary: Defines the type of the bokeh shapes.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehShapeCustom
member.summary: If BokehShape is set to Custom, then this texture will be used for the bokeh shapes. For best performance, use small, compressed, grayscale textures (for instance 32px).

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehBrightnessThreshold
member.summary: The minimum pixel brightness to create the bokeh. Pixels with lower brightness will be skipped.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehBlurThreshold
member.summary: Depth of Field bokeh shape blur threshold.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehFalloff
member.summary: Controls bokeh shape brightness falloff. Higher values reduce bokeh visibility.

member.name: F:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.BokehDepthCutoff
member.summary: Controls bokeh shape generation for depth discontinuities.

member.name: P:FlaxEngine.DepthOfFieldSettings.Default
member.summary: The default .
